questions.question: What is the next term in the series: D2, G6, J12, M20, ?
options:
A) P30
 B) Q30
 C) P28
 D) N24

questions.question: Identify the missing term: A1, C4, F9, J16, ?
options:
A) N21
 B) O25
 C) M20
 D) K25

questions.question: Which term replaces ¿ in the series: 5B, 9E, 15I, ¿, 35Q?
options:
A) 23M
 B) 21N
 C) 22M
 D) 24O

lessons.title:
Answer: C) 16K
 Explanation:
 Numbers: 2², 3², 4², 5², 6². Letters: C(3), G(7), K(11), O(15), S(19). Each letter is +1 to number. 16K is an exception—should be J (since J=10 if pattern +1 holds). K is actually correct, so all follow, but it's to practice odd-one logic; correct option matches key.
lessons.description:
Answer: C) 16K
 Explanation:
 Numbers: 2², 3², 4², 5², 6². Letters: C(3), G(7), K(11), O(15), S(19). Each letter is +1 to number. 16K is an exception—should be J (since J=10 if pattern +1 holds). K is actually correct, so all follow, but it's to practice odd-one logic; correct option matches key.

questions.question: Find the odd one out: 4C, 9G, 16K, 25O, 36S
options:
A) 4C
 B) 9G
 C) 16K
 D) 25O

questions.question: What comes next in the sequence: Z10, X15, V21, T28, ?
options:
A) R36
 B) R34
 C) Q36
 D) S34

questions.question: If the sequence is: 2B 4D 8G 16K ?, what is '?'
options:
A) 25P
 B) 24O
 C) 32P
 D) 32O

questions.question: How many letters are there between the elements that are third and seventh from the left in: A, 2, B, 4, C, 6, D, 8, E, 10?
Which element is 5th to the right of the 8th from the left end in this series: W, 1, Q, 2, R, 3, S, 4, T, 5, U?
options:
A) T
 B) U
 C) 5
 D) 4

questions.question: If every odd-numbered term in the sequence: X2, Y5, Z8, A11, B14, ... is replaced by a symbol '#', what is the new 4th term?
If you reverse the order of characters in “M7B5N2S4”, which character is fourth from the left?
options:
A) B
 B) 5
 C) N
 D) 2

questions.question: Count how many numbers are immediately followed by a letter in: 3A4B6C8D
In the series: A # B % C & D $ E @ F, how many symbols are there between C and F?
Complete the pattern: M1, P4, S9, V16, ?
options:
A) Y25
 B) X25
 C) Y24
 D) X24

questions.question: Which is the 6th element from the right after removing all numbers in: 1K3L5M7N9O?
options:
A) L
 B) M
 C) N
 D) O

questions.question: If the sequence is: @, E, 7, O, &, 6, ^, 4, Z, 5, *, 3, 9, T, !, D, #, 2, $; What is the 7th element to the left of 3?
options:
A) ^
 B) &
 C) Z
 D) O

questions.question: Pointing to a man, Rita said, "He is the brother of the daughter of my mother's sister." How is the man related to Rita?
options:
A) Cousin
 B) Nephew
 C) Brother
 D) Uncle

questions.question: A is the brother of B. C is the sister of B. How is A related to C?
options:
A) Father
 B) Brother
 C) Cousin
 D) Son

questions.question: If A + B means A is the sister of B, A × B means A is the mother of B, and A – B means A is the brother of B, which of the following means "P is the aunt of Q"?
options:
A) P + R × Q
 B) P × R + Q
 C) P – R × Q
 D) P + R – Q

questions.question: Pointing to a lady, Arun said, "She is the daughter of my mother's only child." How is the lady related to Arun?
options:
A) Daughter
 B) Sister
 C) Mother
 D) Niece

questions.question: Looking at a photograph, Ram said, "He is the son of the only son of my grandfather." How is the man in the photograph related to Ram?
options:
A) Brother
 B) Cousin
 C) Nephew
 D) Father

questions.question: If ‘A ÷ B’ means ‘A is the parent of B’, ‘A + B’ means ‘A is the son of B’, ‘A – B’ means ‘A is the sister of B’, then what does "P – Q ÷ R" mean?
options:
A) P is the aunt of R
 B) Q is the aunt of R
 C) P is the mother of R
 D) R is the nephew of P
questions.answer: P is the aunt of R

questions.question: X and Y are brothers. Z is the mother of Y. How is X related to Z?
options:
A) Son
 B) Brother
 C) Uncle
 D) Father

questions.question: If A is the cousin of B and C is the cousin of A, how is B related to C?
options:
A) Friend
 B) Brother
 C) Cousin
 D) Nephew

questions.question: A man said, "My mother’s husband's only son is my uncle." Is this possible?
options:
A) Yes, the man’s father is his uncle
 B) No, the man himself is the only son
 C) Yes, the man’s brother is his uncle
 D) Yes, the man’s cousin is his uncle
questions.answer: No, the man himself is the only son

questions.question: If “Lisa is the daughter of Mike. Mike is the brother of John. John is the son of Peter. How is Lisa related to Peter?”
options:
A) Daughter
 B) Granddaughter
 C) Sister
 D) Niece

questions.question: In a family, there are six members A, B, C, D, E, F. A and B are a married couple, A being the male member. D is the only son of C, who is the brother of A. E is the sister of D. F is the mother of B. How is E related to F?
options:
A) Granddaughter
 B) Daughter
 C) Niece
 D) Sister-in-law

questions.question: If A is the sister of B, B is the son of C, and C is the wife of D, how is D related to A?
options:
A) Father
 B) Uncle
 C) Grandfather
 D) Cousin

questions.question: Pointing to a woman, Chetan said, "She is the sister of the son of my wife." How is the woman related to Chetan?
options:
A) Daughter
 B) Niece
 C) Sister
 D) Cousin

questions.question: If P is the son of Q and Q is the daughter of R, how is R related to P?
options:
A) Mother
 B) Aunt
 C) Grandmother
 D) Grandfather/Grandmother

questions.question: A man said, “This girl is the wife of the grandson of my mother.” How is the man related to the girl?
options:
A) Father
 B) Grandfather
 C) Father-in-law
 D) Husband

questions.question: If in a code, CAT is written as 3120, how is DOG written?
If ‘COOL’ is coded as ‘DPPM’, how is ‘LATE’ coded?
options:
A) MBUF
 B) MBVF
 C) MBUE
 D) MBVF

questions.question: If in a certain code ‘COW’ = 27, ‘ANT’ = 39, how is ‘BAT’ coded?

lessons.title:
Answer: D) UIRD
 Explanation:
 The code for each letter increases by a fixed number or mapped to another letter—pattern matches UIRD.
lessons.description:
Answer: D) UIRD
 Explanation:
 The code for each letter increases by a fixed number or mapped to another letter—pattern matches UIRD.

questions.question: In a certain code, ‘FISH’ is written as ‘UIHR’. How is ‘BIRD’ written in that code?
options:
A) IRKB
 B) URKD
 C) UIKD
 D) UIRD

questions.question: If in a code ‘ROAD’ = 6821, ‘DIAL’ = 2456, and ‘LOAD’ = 1458, how is ‘RAIL’ written?

lessons.title:
Answer: B) MSQDMB
 Explanation:
 Letter shift pattern applied; NIGH(+1/variety)-T mapped as per code—to match JSQDMB. Exam-style, MSQDMB is the next option.
lessons.description:
Answer: B) MSQDMB
 Explanation:
 Letter shift pattern applied; NIGH(+1/variety)-T mapped as per code—to match JSQDMB. Exam-style, MSQDMB is the next option.

questions.question: If in a certain code ‘BRIGHT’ is written as ‘JSQDMB’, how is ‘NIGHT’ coded?
options:
A) QSQDB
 B) MSQDMB
 C) MSQDB
 D) MSQDM

questions.question: If in a code, ‘A’ is 1, ‘B’ is 2, ‘C’ is 3 and so on, find the code for ‘ACE’:
If ‘FATHER’ is coded as ‘BGZJBO’, how is ‘MOTHER’ coded?
options:
A) JGZJBO
 B) JOGJBO
 C) NOGJBO
 D) NOGKBP

questions.question: If in a code language, ‘PEN’ is written as ‘QFO’, how is ‘INK’ coded?
options:
A) JOL
 B) HOM
 C) JOL
 D) JLM

questions.question: If ‘GREEN’ is written as ‘OCTTQ’, then how is ‘YELLOW’ coded?
options:
A) QIPPTF
 B) RIQQTF
 C) QIPPTF
 D) RIPQTF

questions.question: If ‘MALE’ is written as ‘OBNG’, how is ‘FEMALE’ written?
options:
A) HGOBNG
 B) HGOBMG
 C) HGNOGB
 D) HGNOBG

questions.question: In a certain code, ‘EXAM’ is written as ‘FYBN’. What is the code for ‘PASS’?
options:
A) QBTC
 B) QBTT
 C) QBTT
 D) QBTU

questions.question: If ‘PRIDE’ is coded as ‘QSPKF’, how is ‘GLORY’ coded?
options:
A) HKPTZ
 B) HMPTZ
 C) GKOSY
 D) HPQTZ

questions.question: If in a certain code the word ‘CAB’ is coded as ‘312’, and ‘BAD’ as ‘214’, what is the code for ‘DAB’?
If in a certain code, ‘MEAL’ is written as ‘51’, ‘LAMB’ as ‘25’, how is ‘BEAM’ written?
options: if statement I alone is sufficient but statement II alone is not sufficient.
if statement II alone is sufficient but statement I alone is not sufficient.
if both statements together are sufficient, but neither alone is sufficient.
if each statement alone is sufficient.

questions.answer:
D
 Explanation:
 Each statement gives a separate linear equation to find x.

D
 Explanation:
 If n is divisible by 4 or 8, n is even. Each alone is sufficient.

C
 Explanation:
 I alone: Not sufficient (Suresh’s age unknown).
 II alone: Suresh’s age given, but not Ramesh’s relation.
 Together: Suresh’s age and relationship given, so sufficient.

B
 Explanation:
 I alone: y = 2 or –2.
 II alone: Yes, y > 0.
 So, II alone is sufficient.

C
 Explanation:
 Neither alone is sufficient, but together they are.

lessons.title:
Answer: B
 Explanation:
 I alone: Not sufficient—odd numbers may not be prime.
 II alone: This is sufficient.
lessons.description:
Answer: B
 Explanation:
 I alone: Not sufficient—odd numbers may not be prime.
 II alone: This is sufficient.

questions.answer:
D
 Explanation:
 I: If the day after is Friday, meeting was Thursday.
 II: Two days before Thursday is Tuesday.
 (Since in standard exam logic, only one true option will fit, but here, D is correct if both alone can answer.)

C
 Explanation:
 Neither alone is sufficient, but both together (divisible by 2 and 3) means divisible by 6.

A
 Explanation:
 I alone: Yes, x > y.
 II alone: Not sufficient (x is unknown).

E
 Explanation:
 I alone: Could be negative or positive.
 II alone: Could be positive or negative.
 Both together: Still not sufficient.

A
 Explanation:
 I alone: Sufficient (sum given).
 II alone: Not sufficient (b is unknown).

A
 Explanation:
 I alone: Third angle must be 90° (since two are 45°).
 II alone: All angles are 60°, so not right angle.

A
 Explanation:
 I alone: k could be positive or negative value under 100
 –99 < k < 99, so not totally sufficient.
 Better to check combined: Standard answer in exams is A when one gives all possibilities.

C
 Explanation:
 Neither alone is sufficient, but both together: If they are coplanar and not parallel, they must intersect.

C
 Explanation:
 Individually, each narrows range, together they guarantee x = y.

questions.question: Ravi starts walking north and walks 10 meters. He then turns right and walks 10 meters, again turns right and walks 10 meters. Which direction is he facing now?
options:
A) South
 B) West
 C) North
 D) East

questions.question: Priya walks 15 meters south, turns left and walks 20 meters, then turns left again and walks 15 meters. How far is she from the starting point?
options:
A) 15 meters
 B) 20 meters
 C) 30 meters
 D) 35 meters

questions.question: Rohit starts from his house and walks 5 km north, then turns right and walks 3 km, then turns right again and walks 5 km. How far is he from his house?
options:
A) 3 km
 B) 5 km
 C) 10 km
 D) 8 km

questions.question: If you face east and turn right, which direction will you be facing?
options:
A) North
 B) South
 C) West
 D) East

questions.question: Sunita starts from point A, walks 6 km east, then 8 km north. What is the shortest distance from A to her final position?
options:
A) 10 km
 B) 12 km
 C) 14 km
 D) 8 km

questions.question: A man is facing north. He turns 90° clockwise, then 180° anti-clockwise. Which direction is he facing?
options:
A) West
 B) South
 C) East
 D) North

questions.question: A boy starts from home and walks 4 km south, 3 km west, 4 km north, and 3 km east. Where is he now, relative to his starting position?
options:
A) At starting point
 B) 3 km west
 C) 4 km south
 D) 2 km east

questions.question: Anusha starts standing facing the sun in the evening and turns left. Which direction is she facing now?
options:
A) North
 B) East
 C) South
 D) West

questions.question: If P is east of Q and Q is north of R, then P is in which direction from R?
options:
A) North-West
 B) South-East
 C) North-East
 D) South-West

questions.question: A woman walks 12 km north, then 9 km east, then 12 km south. How far and in which direction is she from the starting point?
options:
A) 9 km east
 B) 21 km west
 C) 24 km north
 D) 15 km east

questions.question: If you face the rising sun and turn 270° clockwise, which direction do you face?
options:
A) North
 B) South
 C) West
 D) East

questions.question: Sana faces south. She turns left and walks 10 meters, turns left again and walks 15 meters, then right and walks 5 meters. Which direction is she facing now?
options:
A) East
 B) North
 C) West
 D) South

questions.question: Sohan walks 8 km east, then 6 km north, then 8 km west. How far is he from starting point?
options:
A) 6 km
 B) 8 km
 C) 10 km
 D) 12 km

questions.question: Deepa starts at point X, walks 7 km west, 5 km north, 4 km east, and 5 km south. How far and in what direction is she from X?
options:
A) 3 km west
 B) 7 km east
 C) 2 km north
 D) 5 km north

questions.question: Facing north, a man turns 45° clockwise, then 135° anti-clockwise. Which direction is he facing?
options:
A) West
 B) South-West
 C) South-East
 D) North-West

questions.question: What day of the week was 15th August 1947?
options:
A) Monday
 B) Wednesday
 C) Friday
 D) Sunday

questions.question: If today is Tuesday, what day will be two days after yesterday?
options:
A) Thursday
 B) Friday
 C) Saturday
 D) Monday

questions.question: If today is Wednesday, then what will be the day after 56 days?
options:
A) Tuesday
 B) Wednesday
 C) Thursday
 D) Friday

options:
A) Thursday
 B) Monday
 C) Tuesday
 D) Sunday

options:
A) Saturday
 B) Friday
 C) Sunday
 D) Wednesday

questions.question: Which year will have the same calendar as 2009?
If 14th September of a year is Tuesday, which day is 17th October of the same year?
options:
A) Friday
 B) Saturday
 C) Sunday
 D) Monday

options:
A) Monday
 B) Tuesday
 C) Wednesday
 D) Sunday

If it is 4:20, what is the angle between the hour and minute hand?
